posts.name:
Muskan Agarwal
Muskan Agarwal
posts.content:
Controversy is 

Let me tell you what I mean- 

As a personal branding agency we understand how important it is for founders to reach to a large set of their target audience.

Currently we are working with some of the top founders globally and to them their reputation matters the most and of course for all the right reasons.

Whenever we ask our clients to post controversial content their is always a reluctance and of course putting out even a little bit of wrong content from their profile can do more harm than good.

But let me tell you what we tell them-

controversy doesn‚Äôt always have to be negative it can just be like an unpopular opinion that they have on certain things.

Example - I did a post on how working on vacations in fine. It got me 500k+ impressions in a month and my DMs flooded.

Was it something negative ? No
It was just a unpopular opinion that a lot of people don‚Äôt agree with and a lot of people who agree stopped because they can finally see someone talk about it in publish.

Both of which is fine.

As a human you are not bound to agree to everything and till the time you are not being negative or being hurtful to anyone it‚Äôs absolutely fine to put your opinion forward.

And trust me most of the successful founders have a lot of things that probably do not align with what most people belief in.

Do you think putting out controversial / unpopular opinions is necessary?

comments.commentText: Completely necessary many times, if we want to survive

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Sharing unpopular opinions can spark meaningful conversations and showcase authenticity. It‚Äôs all about balance and intent.

posts.name:
David Lorango
David Lorango
posts.content: There's a fine line between limiting yourself and knowing your limits. And finding that line is a key to success.
posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Embracing our boundaries while pushing them can lead to growth and new opportunities. Finding that balance is essential!

posts.name:
Dan Mian
Dan Mian
posts.content:
Rejection hurts.
Job searching can feel relentless.

You spend hours:

- Tailoring your CV
- Crafting applications
- Preparing for interviews

You go through multiple rounds.
Each one building your hopes higher.

And then an email lands in your inbox:
‚ÄúWe regret to inform you.‚Äù

It‚Äôs brutal.
I‚Äôve been there.

I was rejected 50 times before I landed my dream job.

But here‚Äôs what every job seeker needs to know...

Rejection is normal.
It‚Äôs not a reflection of your worth or potential.

What matters is how you respond to it.

Here‚Äôs How To Turn Rejection Into Success:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Ask For Feedback
‚Ü≥ Find out why you weren't selected.
‚Ü≥ Apply what you learn for future applications.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Customise Your CV For Each Application
‚Ü≥ Highlight results & use keywords from job description.
‚Ü≥ Adopt the employers language.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Practice Interviewing
‚Ü≥ Don't relax once you land an interview.
‚Ü≥ Rehearse answers, record yourself & refine your answers.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Stay In Touch With Interviewers
‚Ü≥ Send a thank-you message, even if you‚Äôre rejected.
‚Ü≥ Ask for future opportunities when they come up.

After being rejected from the Civil Service, my client stayed in touch with the interviewer.

They reached out - he landed the new role!

6Ô∏è‚É£ Track Your Progress
‚Ü≥ Create a tracker for applications, follow-ups & feedback.
‚Ü≥ Spot patterns in your approach (e.g. applying earlier = more success).

7Ô∏è‚É£ Take Care Of Yourself
‚Ü≥ Rejection is tough - give yourself time to process it.
‚Ü≥ Celebrate small wins to keep your momentum going.

A ‚Äúno‚Äù today is not a ‚Äúno‚Äù tomorrow.

Every rejection brings you closer to the right opportunity.

Trust the process.
Keep learning, improving & moving forward.

You‚Äôve got this!

Ô∏è Repost to inspire job seekers.
 Followfor more career advice.

_________________

Are You A Graduate In The UK Looking For Your Dream Job? 

I'm hosting a FREE job search masterclass on Wednesday.
Comment "Dream Job" to get the invite ‚¨áÔ∏è

comments.commentText: I love how you've shared your personal experience of being rejected 50 times before landing your dream job. Your 7 tips on turning rejection into success are super valuable, especially asking for feedback, customizing your CV, and taking care of yourself. Thanks for the inspiration,.

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Rejection is tough, but the path to success is paved with resilience. Keep pushing forward‚Äîyour dream job is within reach! üöÄ

posts.name:
Shima Ghaheri
Shima Ghaheri
posts.content:
Last week, 102 professionals signed up
for my ‚ÄúLand Your Dream Job‚Äù workshop.  

Since then, one question keeps popping up about networking:
‚ÄúWhy would someone respond to me? I‚Äôm just a stranger.‚Äù

Fair point. And if your outreach sounds like:

"Hi, here‚Äôs my portfolio‚Ä¶ thoughts?‚Äù
‚ÄúAny jobs at your company?‚Äù
‚ÄúCan I pick your brain?‚Äù
(Translation: can I get free advice that took you 10 years to learn?)


...it‚Äôs no wonder your inbox is quieter than a library at midnight.

And when the response doesn‚Äôt come? Cue the spiral:

‚Üí Was my message bad?
‚Üí Did they hate me? Am I screwed?
‚Üí Maybe I should‚Äôve used more emojis.

The truth?
It‚Äôs not about emojis.
It‚Äôs about your mindset.

You‚Äôve got to approach outreach with a
‚Äúyou mindset,‚Äù not a ‚Äúme mindset.‚Äù


Want to know how to stand out and actually get responses?
I‚Äôm breaking it all down tomorrow in my newsletter.

If you‚Äôre tired of hearing crickets after your outreach, this is for you:

comments.commentText:
Shima Ghaheri That's AMAZING! The "You" mindset is everything! 

What would you say is the ONE tip that you would give to help someone stuck in the "me" mindset?

posts.commentAdded: Love this perspective! Shifting from a ‚Äúme‚Äù to a ‚Äúyou‚Äù mindset makes all the difference in networking. Excited for your insights in the newsletter! üöÄ

posts.name:
Michael Ocean
Michael Ocean
posts.content:
Enablement is not a vending machine - stop treating it like one!


I recently had a conversation with(Director of Learning Design at JLL, formerly led enablement at Outreach). She shared a powerful perspective on why most enablement initiatives fail: treating enablement like a vending machine instead of a strategic partner.


Key insight: You can't just push a button and get instant results. Like any good sales process, enablement needs discovery:

- What's the real problem you're trying to solve?
- Has this training been done before?
- How will we measure success?
- What's the timeline for meaningful impact?


In the full episode, we covered:

- How JLL runs their "Power Hour" program across 600+ global sellers
- Practical frameworks for building sustainable enablement programs
- Strategies for engaging multi-generational remote teams
- Why random training requests kill enablement effectiveness
- Tips for aligning with sales leaders and getting executive buy-in


Something that really stood out: Brooke's team maintains a 70/30 split between programmatic and ad-hoc enablement - proving you can balance structure with flexibility.


Want to hear the full conversation on building effective everboarding programs?

Check out the link in comments

comments.commentText: Love this! The vending machine days are over!

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Treating enablement as a strategic partner is crucial for lasting success. Excited to hear more about those frameworks!

posts.name:
Hussein Al-Baiaty
Hussein Al-Baiaty
posts.content:
For authors and experts scrolling LinkedIn today.

Engagement isn‚Äôt just about what you post‚Äîit‚Äôs about how you show up for others.

While you‚Äôre here, take a moment to create a connection opportunity.

Share one thoughtful comment with a tip or insight.

Offer a unique perspective in a conversation.

Support a smaller creator by engaging with their content.

Start a relatable comment with, ‚ÄúWhenever I [action]‚Ä¶‚Äù to create connection.

Leave a positive comment that brightens someone‚Äôs day.

Every time someone sees your name, they should think, ‚ÄúThis person is interested in my work and is valuable.‚Äù

Building relationships matters just as much as posting.

Show up, and you‚Äôll start seeing the impact.

comments.commentText: Raju Pawar small actions big rewards

posts.commentAdded: Whenever I engage with others posts, I discover incredible insights and build meaningful connections. Lets support each other!
